awd_titl_txt: WoU-MMA: Multi-Messenger and Multi-Wavelength Particle Astrophysics with HAWC
awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation.  Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe and can be used to test fundamental physics.  The High Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) observatory, located on the slopes of the Sierra Negra in Mexico, is a ground-based facility designed with unique capabilities to observe very high-energy gamma rays.  This award supports scientists at Michigan State University doing research with HAWC.  In addition to activities in support of HAWC operations, the group will use HAWC data to explore the origin and acceleration of particles in extreme physical environments.  They will also use HAWC observations to search for gamma-ray counterparts of high-energy neutrinos detected by the IceCube Neutrino Observatory.  The group will engage in education and public outreach activities, including installing a HAWC exhibit at the Michigan State University Abrams Planetarium.

HAWC is a wide field of view, continuously operating observatory.  Unlike more traditional ground-based telescopes that point at a small region of sky on clear nights, HAWC has the ability to study very extended regions of gamma-ray emission and to nearly-continuously monitor time-varying phenomena.  The Michigan State University group will capitalize on these abilities by compiling a catalog of time-varying gamma-ray sources and looking for correlations with high-energy neutrino events recorded by the IceCube Neutrino Observatory and lower energy gamma-ray emission recorded by the Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope.  The group will also conduct a search for dark matter signals coming from the extended halo around the Galactic Center.  This work directly addresses the goals of NSF's "Windows on the Universe: The Era of Multi-Messenger Astrophysics" Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The High-Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) Gamma-ray Observatory is the most sensitive, wide field-of-view, TeV gamma-ray observatory ever built. It has been operating at >90% uptime with the full array since 2015 and provides a new look at the gamma-ray sky by discovering new sources, observing sources at the highest energies ever seen, and indirectly searching for dark matter at the highest masses. The MSU group has played a key role in these achievements by using their expertise to improve HAWC's sensitivity through better detector simulation, background rejection and energy resolution. These improvements are being applied to all HAWC's science analyses. This project used a neural network technique to improve HAWC's detector energy resolution and then applied it to several analyses that led to publications. The new energy estimator greatly improved HAWC's resolution at the highest energies allowing the measurement of the Crab nebula spectrum over 100 TeV. This was then used to publish the first catalog of gamma ray sources that emit photons above 56 TeV. The highest energy photon events (>100 TeV) were then used to set the world's most stringent limits (for some models) on Lorentz Invariance Violation (LIV). A new catalog of astronomical sources, the third or 3HWC, was compiled using these improvements. In addition, a search for TeV gamma-ray emission from classical novae that were observed in the radio and GeV (Fermi) wavelengths was published and preliminary results on TeV gamma rays from the Sun was shown at an international conference.

As an all-sky, continuously observing instrument HAWC serves as a finder telescope and monitors the same sky as Imaging Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescopes (VERITAS, MAGIC, H.E.S.S), gamma-ray satellites (Fermi), gravitational wave detectors (LIGO) and neutrino observatories (IceCube) allowing for multi-wavelength and multi-messenger observations. This project used HAWC's ability to monitor flaring or transient objects to search for evaporating primordial black holes (PBHs), that would look like gamma-ray bursts, to set the strongest limit on the local PBH burst rate density from any existing electromagnetic measurement. HAWC's indirect searches for dark matter extend to WIMP masses higher than any other gamma-ray experiment. This project searched for dark matter from multiple sources including the Galactic halo, the Virgo cluster and dwarf spheroidal galaxies. A multi-wavelength analysis combining HAWC's search for dark matter from dwarf spheroidal galaxies was combined with 4 other gamma-ray experiments (VERITAS, MAGIC, H.E.S.S, and Fermi) giving the world's strongest limits on dark matter cross-sections over several mass ranges. This project also performed a multi-messenger analysis search for TeV gamma-ray counterparts to IceCube's high-energy neutrino events. Two of the graduate students on this project won NSF Graduate Research Fellowships with proposals to do multi-messenger analyses with HAWC and IceCube.

 

Broader Impacts:

Particle astrophysics is a field that excites the imagination of all people, from the public to students. The research team has participated in many outreach, diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) efforts aimed at educating students as well as the public about their exciting research on HAWC. For example, members of the project have provided lectures and activities related to HAWC at various summer camps aimed at middle and high schoolers from marginalize backgrounds. The group has participated in public outreach venues, such as the MSU Science Fest and public lectures.

This project has supported and trained a postdoc, 5 graduate students and 3 undergraduate students. Two of the graduate students received their PhDs and two of the undergrads did senior theses on this project. The project has trained a diverse group of people, including several from historically marginalized groups in STEM, who serve as role models to others. The team of researchers on the project included a Latino graduate student, an African American graduate student and 4 women: the PI, a postdoc, a graduate student, and an undergrad. This project makes use of machine learning techniques, such as neural networks, to improve the resolution of the HAWC detector and event reconstruction. This has led to 2 recent MSU PhD graduate students that worked on this project to acquire jobs as data scientists.
